STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 19, 2025
Jamie Prewozniak
DA BLODGETT FOR CHILDREN
2172 Dean Lake Ave NE,
Grand Rapids, MI, 49505-4444
Re: License #: CB410201088
Dear Jamie Prewozniak:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
May 15, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410201088
Licensee Group Organization: DA Blodgett for Children
Licensee Designee: Joel Timothy Bell
Chief Administrator: Jamie Prewozniak
Name of Agency: DA BLODGETT FOR CHILDREN
Agency Address: 2172 Dean Lake Ave NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49505-4444
Agency Telephone #: 6164512021
Original Issuance Date: 06/02/1991
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (d) Three references obtained from persons
who are unrelated to the staff person.
Three of eighteen new employee files reviewed did have verification 3 references
were obtained prior to hire.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (b) Verification of education.
Two of eighteen new employee files reviewed did not have verification of education
as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/1/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/9/2024
2

CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (h) Documentation from the department
that the person has not been named in a
central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any
state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
One of eighteen new employee files reviewed did not contain documentation of an
out of state central registry clearance was completed prior to hire.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
• (a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or
not later than 6 months after the staff
member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation,
a written evaluation must be conducted
every 12 months.
Two of twenty-one employee files reviewed did not have a performance evaluation
completed either within 6 months of hire or annually as required.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (4) At least 1 adult member of the household must
have training in and maintain a current certification
in first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from
the American Heart Association or the American
Red Cross, or other institution approved by the
department.
One of six foster home files reviewed did not have documentation of current
CPR/First Aid certification as required.
3

CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of children
preferred by the applicants.
One of six foster home files reviewed did not document preferred placement
specifications regarding SOGIE.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to
possible noncompliance with any foster home
rule, the agency must do all the following:
• (a) Submit a special investigation record to
the department's licensing authority within 5
working days in the manner prescribed by
the department.
One of three special investigations reviewed did not submit a special investigation
record to the department's licensing authority within 5 working days as required.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (a) The date the information was received.
One of three special investigations reviewed did not have the report completed
within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following in
the child's record before a change of placement
occurs:
4

• (a) Reason for the change in placement.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not document the reason for a change in
placement in the youth's record prior the placement change as required.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (c) A physical examination for each child as
follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
• (i) A comprehensive medical
examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma
screening, within 30 calendar days
from the date the child entered into
an out-of-home placement,
regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation an initial medical
examination was completed within 30 calendar days of the youth entering out-of-
home placement.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents;
the department licensing authority; the
lawyer guardian ad litem and court, as
applicable; the department; and the foster
child's parents, if any of the following
occurs:
• (iv) Any medical and mental illness
or condition that results in treatment
at a hospital emergency room or
inpatient hospitalization of a foster
child.
5

Two of six foster care files reviewed, and one of three independent living files
reviewed did not have documentation an incident report was completed and
required individuals were notified after youth received treatment at a hospital
emergency room.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/1/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/9/2024
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (b) Child's date of birth.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided youth's date of birth prior to placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided youth's name prior to placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (c) Available known information about the
child's health.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided youth's known health information.
6

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect
of the child.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided youth's known abuse/neglect history.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (e) All known emotional and psychological
factors relating to the care of the child.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided youth's known emotional and psychological factors.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided youth's known behaviors.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (g) Circumstances necessitating placement
or replacement of the child.
7

Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided circumstances necessitating placement.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (h) Any other known information to enable
the foster parent to provide a stable, safe,
and healthy environment for the foster child
and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the
foster home as provided in federal law.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided any known information to enable foster parent to provide a safe, stable and
healthy environment for the foster child and the foster family including any sibling
information.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (i) Name of assigned social service worker.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver was
provided the name of assigned social service worker.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Three of six foster care files reviewed and one of three independent living files
reviewed had a service plan submitted outside of the required timeframe.
8

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/1/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/9/2024
5/11/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/15/2023
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
• (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the
foster child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in
the child's placement at least once every month.
Three of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the assigned
case worker completed a visit with the youth in the youth's placement at least once
per month.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
• (2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
agency provided the youth with a copy of the IL program statement prior to
placement in independent living.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
independent living contract was provided to youth quarterly as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/1/2024 RENEWAL, CAP 9/9/2024
5/11/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/15/2023
9

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Make sure all documents are uploaded in the correct location.
• Ensure youth’s physical characteristics are documented in service plans.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency renewal inspection was completed on 5/1/2024 and the CAP was
approved on 9/9/2024. There was a delay due to issues with newly implemented
CAP entry system in CWLM. The agency was cited for 11 violations, 4 of which
were repeated this year. Of those 4, there was an improvement in individual
incidents of non-compliance within 1 of the violation areas and the remaining 3
areas stayed the same. In 2023, 8 violations were established, 4 of which were
repeated this year. All of the repeated violations remain close to the same number
of individual incidents of non-compliances. The agency will need to establish
additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a reduction of
incidents.
Special investigation 2024SIC0001248 was completed on 5/29/2024 and the CAP
was approved on 9/30/2024. The agency was found in non-compliance as the
agency failed to transport a youth's medication to the youth's new location with
resulted in a delay of 16 days the youth was without medication. The agency's
CAP included retraining staff and updating their existing replacement checklist.
The agency has complied with the CAP action steps and no further concerns have
been noted.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated there have been difficulties throughout the year due to extensive staff
turnover. The agency has lost a total of 12 staff who held a variety of positions
10

within foster care. The assessment noted the agency has been able to hire
experienced staff as part of the transition and continue to work to fill vacancies.
The previous year's CAP has been helpful for licensing however the agency is still
working to develop and implement processes for foster care. The agency recently
hired a full-time Performance Quality Improvement (PQI) supervisor who will be
responsible for working with child welfare teams to analyze data, identity barriers
and improve metrics.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and agency's financial audit.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two safety concerns identified.
Safety Alert #1: The relative caregiver was contacted multiple attempts by Agency
Analyst to schedule a home visit and the home refused.
Resolution: Agency supervisor conducted a home visit and was able to confirm the
wellbeing of foster child in the home and verify the home was clean and appropriate.
Relative caregiver explained she recently had a major medical procedure and that
was the reason she declined the visit from Agency Analyst.
Safety Alert #2: The condition of relative caregiver's home was concerning as it was
cluttered and presented a fire hazard as well as a safety hazard. In addition, the
home there were no smoke detectors observed in the home.
Resolution: The agency conducted a home visit and provided relative caregivers
with the required smoke detectors. In addition, a safety plan was established that
included foster youth going to a respite home for the weekend to allow relative
caregiver time to de-clutter and address the fire and safety hazards. Agency
provided photo verification of smoke detectors installed, and the home cleaned up
with safety and sanitary issues addressed.
11

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
__________5/16/2025___________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 19, 2025
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
12
